frameDefinitions: In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
A trial is a process conducted in a Court before a Judge and (usually) a Jury in which the participants meet in order to decide a Case.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
A  Source_of_authority, typically a government, relies upon a set of institutions specialized for the administration of justice.

These words describe how outgoing or sociable a Protagonist is judged to be by a (usually implicit) Judge, often in a particular context, either with certain people (the Company), or about a particular situation, topic or event (the Content).
A group of Arguers (also expressible as Arguer1 and Arguer2) express incompatible opinions or beliefs about an Issue.
frameExamples: He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
The federal <t>judiciary</t>'s certification process is the foundation of the interpreter program. INI DNI
He was <t>shy</t> with strangers and afraid of showing his feelings.
We <t>bickered</t> about semantics for an hour.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The legal label for the crime that the <fen>Defendant</fen> is accused of.
The specific room where the participants in a Trial meet.

The individual or group which is responsible for promoting the welfare of the  <fen>Defendant</fen> during a Trial, usually involving the contention that the <fen>Defendant</fen> is innocent of the <fen>Charges</fen>.
The group of individuals who observe the Trial and ultimately attempt to come to a verdict.
The individual or group responsible for promoting the interests of the state in the Trial, prototypically including presenting arguments for the guilt of the <fen>Defendant</fen>.
The person charged with an offence.
The official who directs and presides over the Trial.
The <fen>Case</fen> which a Trial is convened to decide.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the trial occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the trial occurs.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
A permanent organization with the socially important purpose of administering justice.
The concern of the <fen>Judicial_body</fen>-- broadly speaking, the aspect of society that they affect.

The responsibility that a <fen>Judicial_body</fen> has, either defined in terms of the type of cases that they can hear, or more specifically by reference to an action that the authority constituting them wishes the <fen>Judicial_body</fen>  to achieve.
The geographical area within which the <fen>Judicial_body</fen> has authority and responsibility.
The place where the <fen>Judicial_body</fen> is located.
The Protagonist is the person whose sociability is being described.
The Protagonist may be sociable, shy, outgoing, etc. when with particular Company (specific people or types of people).  Company usually occurs in a PP Complement with a target adjective:
The Protagonist may be sociable, shy, outgoing, etc. when in a particular situation, or about performing some action.
A group of people in an argument.
A person who is arguing with Arguer2.
The person who is being argued with by <fen>Arguer1</fen>.
The the thing the the <fen>Arguers</fen> are arguing over or about.
The time when the argument takes place.
The location at which the <fen>Arguers</fen> quarrel
listRoleExamples: Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
The International Monetary Fund Administrative <fex><t>Tribunal</t></fex> (IMFAT) adjudicates employment disputes between staff members and the IMF.

Anything you say or write can and will be held against you in
a court <fex>of law</fex>.
The International Criminal Tribunal <fex>for Rwanda</fex> sentenced Mikaeli Muhimana on April 28 to life imprisonment.
On February 18, 1983, the Supreme Court <fex>of Alabama</fex> denied this motion.
